WOdI-eyyJXoVIDZdXI48kA.text: Excellent restaurant serving better-quality North Indian cuisine with a modern twist. Very pleasant ambience and attentive staff. The food is excellent and not pricey by the standards of the location. You can often get a table just by walking in earler in the evening. Highly recommended.

pjfcXL2dffshHBHInQrFOA.text: This place has recently reopened after being damaged by smoke a few months ago. A really quality Indian restaurant, although expensive. The menu is full of rich ingredients like rabbit, game, lamb, chicken all done in a variety of good curry sauce bases. An interesting selection of fish and veggie options too. Didnt like the poppadom at the start as these werent fresh. The dips that came with them were also bland. I had the lamb shank which was tender and full of flavour and my friend had the seafood curry. At £18 a plate for main course, this is expensive but by the looks of it there will be some discount on the food.

7tRcXJfxWwm4IcfOzcW3IA.text: I've only been here once for dinner, but will be back.  The food was fantastic and service attentive.  The atmosphere is sort of lounge-y.  I'd recommend coming here for a date night or small group dinner, if you want an Indian meal at a more upscale restaurant.

F5nux1hPCMlITyZ2AmN7vQ.text: The Red Fort was the first place I had "fancy" Indian food, and for that reason, it holds a special place in my heart. The food here is inventive, flavourful, and elegant, and I have never had a bad meal here.  Before I discovered Chutney Mary, which is much closer to home, this was my go-to place for a celebratory dinner.  If you make it for a pre-theatre dinner, it's somewhat affordable to eat here, and for the quality of the food, it feels like a bargain.  Otherwise, if you eat at a normal hour after Grandma has gone to bed, it's the sort of place you definitely want to be someone else's guest when the bill arrives at the end of the night.

AffkHf0xa0YrVZh3hOFBMw.text: Dinner here was amazing. Service was kind a helpful and the food was spectacular!! We got the Dumpukhi Biryani and Murgh Bemisaal for dinner and split both. Both were cooked to perfection and incredibly flavorful. Exactly what I would expect from a good Indian meal.  We also got naan (of course) and finished off with the Funky Pie which was again, amazing. Id would definitely recommend this place to anyone!

ZcXWJvhK_SYrvhbk0ZSPXw.text: The RedFort has one of the finest North Indian cuisine that London has on offer at the moment. A haven for the media moghuls and rich tourists the Fort is well looking into-if only because of its elegant and sleek water feature and antique artefacts. The menu leans strongly towards North Indian Classics and select dishes from the regal kitchens of Lucknow. Hare Kebabs starters-smooth patties containing smooth spinach puree sharpened by piquant mustard greens followed by a satisfying chicken dish cooked with fresh mint,coriander and green chilli paste hit the right spots in the mouth. There is a good selection to choose from for all palates because Indian food does not have to be chili hot to be enjoyed.

AA9oao5BMFNN5t-ZFPMWJw.text: This place was certainly the food highlight of our trip to London.  Their wine selection was enormous, probably around 25-30 pages.  The food was out of this world good, unfortunately we ate so much we didn't leave room for dessert!  The staff there is very attentive and everything was done promptly overall.  Be sure to get a reservation!

kpPUTzLAyvqgqrOf3gUY4w.text: The scene - two blokes been boozing most of the evening in need of some food. It was a late week night. Now I know because I was a little tipsy, I would have happily eaten my right leg if it came with tarka dhal and an onion bhaji, but we ate slowly, savored the taste, talked it through.   The food was fantastic.  Cooked perfectly.The wine was good - had a bottle of NZ malborough - can't go wrong. Service was brilliant - friendly, prompt and not a disparaging look insight.All in all, £120.I've eaten here before and ended up on the decks downstairs (long night) and the food was better this time.Great place if you are entertaining friends or clients.  I'd recommend this place.  Enjoy.

rlV5D8Eori3ICFK_gLrCMw.text: I hadn't been there for 15 years, so decided to walk down memory lane & venture back. the food had always been great, but what I had notice back then was the stuffy atmosphere which as a young adult I hated ! this time the attitude has changed for the better & the food is even more creative!Try the rabbit special & taste how tender it is !!

KAwG2Du2SBoGxGZmZJM60Q.text: A friend took me here over the weekend and I have to say I was very impressed with the food, service and atmosphere. A really great restaurant, I'll certainly come back soon.

jN4e6_DMTrD0tn318r4qFw.text: We came in with great expectations to have an exceptionally good lunch but we were mostly disappointed.The meals were a peculiar mixture of rather average taste but with one excellant part or detail in each dish.So the three of us, my son - himself a professional chef -, my wife and I pushed the two meat dishes, nobody liked, around the table, but we all pulled the quite delicious prawn dish towards us.I ended up only eating rice, naan and chutneys.Service average.Prices undeservedly high.The toilets are really good and clean. For us this place never deserves any best.

YlQZdkzgm4ieHr0a70IpgQ.text: The Red Fort had a big reputation to live up to and it did a pretty good job of it. The food itself was beautifully prepared and served and there were some innovative dishes on the menu. Although I felt the portions were small and none of the dishes on their own blew me away, I left happily fulfilled. In a way I missed the flock wallpaper and sitar music of Brick Lane eateries but appreciated the fact I could have a business meeting in a nice restaurant, with a good ambiance and excellent service and still get my fix of Indian food.

ebBD8DUr_GuWthF0_g_RTA.text: Great Indian food. It is probably more difficult to find bad Indian, but the ambiance here is amazing...and wine list exceptional.

Y9UxawwDNspi86ZjFwA3mQ.text: One of my favorite Indian restaurants in London.  Innovative menu and great presentation.  Somewhat pricey, but probably worth it.  Good wine, too.

bnDwz7hFdL53Bw1Jb8ea5A.text: A fairly average restaurant in my opinion. Nice touches but food was very bland. We went as a party of ten and spent most of the time talking about the average food that was being served. One saving grace was the decor, everything was laid out immaculately. Even the table cloths were being ironed around us as we ate. Very impressive.

r7cM22UELvorliWYqhfiug.text: A rather upscale Indian restaurant good decor with pricy food. Its a nice place for business meeting and nothing more. Food and service was below par. All the waiters were so grim as if they were in a state of mourn.

jTa2hL1YGxLWMSRk_SJNBw.text: Unlike most others here, my own experience of the Red Fort was distinctly underwhelming. Despite it's massive reputation for superb food, neither I nor my wife felt our meals were especially better quality than any number of Indians we have been too - and none of those had been as eye wateringly expensive as this was about to be either. The service too was shocking. We had gone in early so the place was quiet, but the waiter spent the entire meal looking down his nose as us at a time when you might have thought he would have been glad of the business. A real disappointment. Give me the Cinammon Club any day.

TyCtrGoTcNf2tCLn2-nKbA.text: We arrived very late into London and wanted some good tasty food preferably Indian the hotel reception told us to try Red Fort and that it was serving till 11 or 11:30 and that we should walk. We ignored the walk advice but after being in a cab in that area for 10 mins we got the message and walked. Red Fort was far from what I expected it was sumptous inside, great staff, very friendly and accommodating. They brought us drinks while we struggled on what to get from the menu. When the waiter came back we were still undecided. I asked him if he would pick for us and my crew agreed to give it a shot! It was SO worth it. We had the most amazing meal - the appetizer sampler was delicious. The tikka salmon was probably the best piece of fish I have ever eaten. We then had some Lamb Kofti, Chicken tika masala (by special request) and two veggie plates - and a naan sampler (the naan was good not super) but everything else including the wine pairing was stupendous. A meal I will not forget it and I will return to the Red Fort next time I am in London.

jseBYOJlM5wpvNZXbUGTyw.text: Recently refurbished this place looks amazing. There is a wonderful authentic feel to the place which is mixed witn a modern, sleek sheen. The ambience is very chilled out and is a great place to hang out with friends. The food is awesome with all your traditional Indian favs like Chicken Tikka masala, Saag aloo etc. The cooking is top quality but the décor is what makes this place stand out.

nmL0EUA8BCa_tlR7WrAqTg.text: All good bar the prices which are excessive on any scale. Very good food, comfortable relaxing setting. Fashionable eating place. But I'll wait until the lottery win comes in or some one else is paying - before I go back.

CByzqlYyeBl5tBlX9VWLug.text: I would actually give this place 3 stars if I had paid for the meal myself but I don't want to look ungrateful to the lovely man who paid for me - because it was actually very nice. Except, for what you get, eyewateringly expensive. The idea that you pay about £20 for a small bowl of curry just astounded me. £10 for two bowls of rice. Wines starting at well over £20 a bottle One thing I learned from going to India - and eating in places like VJs in Kilburn, is that Indian food is often at its best when it is simple and dirt cheap. Ok, this place is not a curry house - it is an upmarket restaurant - and the quality of the food was excellent. The mixed starter which we shared was really wonderful - interestingly flavoured meat, fish and vegetable and all with lots of chilli which I really enjoyed. And the mains were good. But not spectacular. Service is fine but nothing special - and the 12.5% that is added to the bill does seem a bit much especially when the bill is already so high! I'm not sure I'd come here again - if I was going to pay that much for dinner I would want to go somewhere I thought the money was better spent.

xqiUdWuQYLE2selwWUeBdQ.text: The chef menu was amazing. We were surprised by the amount and diversity of food served to us. We had a bit plate of starters, four different curries with rice, two types of naan bread and two desserts. The menu doesn't include a drink unfortunately, but the food exceeded our expectations. The best indian restaurant in London!

WCuFekm3tu22us6UnDUkQg.text: Delicious. 2 if us got the 2 course for 15 pound special. Everything was tender, flavored perfectly and service was excellent

J9-fxGKIhxVlKkLVekI_LQ.text: I really love the floatingflowers and the candles; it is very relaxing and has an aromatic effect. Theprice is a bit higher but definitely worth a try. Perfect place for a romantic date or even fora business dinner. Highly recommended place to everyone.

VQulcyB8i6ji7yMYNJ8agw.text: Had a spontaneous dinner here and was amazed at how good it was. The food wasn't greasy and heavy like other Indian restaurants. Would definitely recommend and will be back for sure.

kfH_5TYygyXnMAK_DxzVKA.text: This may be treacherous of me, but man the British do Indian food way better than the Americans. This place was delicious - great classic dishes like butter chicken, daal, roti with some funky others like spinach and fenugreek coated paneer (hara kabob).  Their bhuna ghost was phenomenal and just melts in your mouth.  The ambience was nice and the service solid.  Amazing.  Sorry, America.

5-qHS9fVUpz1KvyAlU_-9g.text: would have given this a 5th star but the shrimp was a bit rubbery.  Every other dish was delish, even the bunny.

n_P85O-418tTPBqoDgVTDg.text: Yum, yum, yum, this place is great.They have a huge wine list -- the first page is an index to the 25+ pages of wine from all over the world. We had a great Stellenbosch cab -- highly recommended if you're looking for a bold and well-priced wine that can stand up to spicy food. If you'd like to try some variety, the starter plate is a good way to go and feeds two. There were some surprising dishes that I would never have ordered that ended up being fantastic, such as the spinach and cheese patty and the mushrooms. Try each dish with each of the different sauces.If you like spicy peppers, you'll love the eggplant. My favorite vegetable dish was okra with asparagus.They have a pretty wide range of desserts -- the next table got the fruit plate and it looked amazingly huge and fresh -- but I was too stuffed from the other food.Gluten-free notes: If you stay away from the naan, there isn't a lot that you can't eat. Even the pappadams they bring at the beginning of the meal don't have wheat (checked with the chef on that one). Enjoy!

GMEGAkxoSNjefUK7PtolNg.text: Best paneer I've ever had.  Great curries.  After lunch, I wanted to go back for dinner.Easy place to recommend if you enjoy Indian food.

RbZS6zlFKftoiFDxixmF9g.text: When I was told we were going here for dinner last Wednesday I'd assumed it was a "normal" curry house. When we got there and looked at the menu, I realised it wasn't that at all. This place definitely sells itself as gourmet Indian and its priced to match. The breads and chutneys were very nice, the breads especially so. I had sheek kebab to start, this was good but could have been moister. For main couse I wanted something spicy so chose the prawn dish, which is the only one that sounded like it would be quite hot. Unfortunately it wasn't very hot, and the sauce lacked a bit of flavour, and the prawns were a bit chewy and again lacked flavour. I also finished off Gill's chicken dish, which was a lot like a tikka masala, which was genuinely amazing.

jTRBKC3HC26V6ZMcqfDMOQ.text: Great place for a visitor to have a night out in London - cool neighborhood, yummy "posh"  Indian food and a nice upscale atmosphere.We started with a cocktail at the bar downstairs.  Lots of great drink options in a chic loungy bar.  This is not your traditional Indian food, it's much more elegant and inventive.  You can order seafood, rabbit and lamb dishes that look amazing, or the more typical chicken and veggie dishes.  I stuck with the more traditional (dal, saag paneer), and it was delicious.  Service was attentive and friendly.  I'd definitely go back the next time I'm in London.

PHF1qYSfyDJDcxjZIrLMhg.text: I love Indian food at home in Denver and I definitely needed an Indian fix while I am studying here in London.  They had an extensive wine list of 25 plus pages that were from all over the world.  I had a wonderful Sauvignon  Blanc (if you haven't noticed that's my favorite type of white wine).  It was a nice pairing with the spicy salmon that I had while I was there.We ordered from the pre-theater menu.  You get two courses for 16 pounds which is not a bad deal at all.  I had a starter of tandoori chicken.  It was wonderful and I really enjoyed it.  I then followed with the salmon with spinach.  The spinach was buttered and had some spices that were added to it.  The salmon definitely did not disappoint.  I was happy I stepped outside the box because normally I just order tandoori chicken at Indian restaurants.  I recommend that you go in and take advantage of their pre-theater menu you can't go wrong with two courses with 16 pounds.  Especially at the quality of food for which they food is at.

yf2SLnseCkNytukx9JO7vQ.text: Living or working in London for the last 10 years, I've come to settle on a handful of "go-to" places for wonderful meals and Red Fort is one of them.   You could imagine my shock when I learned a few years ago that a fire had gutted the place.  I am happy to report, however, that the new, rebuilt 'Fort is better than ever.Of course, there is no lack of curry joints in the UK, so it really takes something to stand out.   There are good alternatives in London - Bombay Brasserie (superb high-end, but too traditional) and Cinnamon Club (Amazing space and and great food, but super pricey) - but the Red Fort combines the combination of excellent atmosphere, superb food and a great Soho location.The wine and cocktails are a great place to start.   A substantial cocktail menu brings a combination of amazing, unique drinks to the table - don't skip them.   The wine menu is worldly, but a bit overpriced, IMO.  Nonetheless, there is an excellent selection.  I would first suggest anything from the tandoori oven.  The meats are simply spectacular.  Monkfish: out of this world.  Chicken:  as juicy and flavorful as you can get.   Lamb:  juicy and flavorful.The rest of the menu is unique.  You won't find your traditional Indian dishes here.  Their curries are marvelous.  The Biryani is to die for.  Don't forget the sides, especially their signature paneer. You might be able to deal with the spices, but the check might make you shed a tear.  This is not your 9.99 Chicken Tikka Masala.  But for a special Indian treat, I think it's worth it.

Dzgh41fbu_GopVtPFUIZvg.text: Red Fort is a high end Indian Fusion/Creative restaurant, similar to Amaya. I really liked the monk fish starter. I tried the grilled and curry infused lobster, which was interesting, but too pricey to be repeated. The standard curries are good, but not particularly interesting or exceptional. You definitely want to try the creative foods that you won't find at the more traditional Indian curry restaurants, say like a Punjab or Tiger Spice. The ambiance is fantastic, a great place to take a date to or for a business dinner. With a glass of wine, starter, a main, a veggie dish to share and naan and rice, it was about 30 quids a person.

Io9GjCjAuow-4D220KV5Nw.text: Food was really good. The chicken tandoori is a must try. It was so succulent and perfectly cooked. However, it is really overpriced for what you're getting. We only went here our first night based on the recommendation from our hotel. Lots of other great options that are less pricey.

EIlH2vULWf1-f1Xz0ttUGw.text: While in London I felt I had to get Indian.  I've heard a lot of good things regarding Indian fare in London.  Since I love Indian, I was down.  We chose this place from Yelp reviews I think.  Between the two of us we seriously tried most of the menu.  It was a nice location, clean interior, the prices comparable and the food solid.  Was I blown away? No.  Could I get just as good indian by going two blocks out my front door in San Francisco, absolutely.  Also the chai wasn't as good as I hoped.

uSz3be1o76OhMUa9tbtOwg.text: 5 pounds for rice and nan is too much.  Really good grilled kingfish, but other items that we had were not that amazing.  Hair in food did not help.

YUGfBUvG08wWl14su-IsHw.text: I really enjoyed this restaurant last time I was in London. The bread in particular was amazing. We chatted up the very handsome waiter, so he took my girlfriend and me for a quick tour of the kitchen. The chef showed us how he makes the bread (by slapping the dough inside a giant clay pot). Very cool. Everyone there was so nice. I really enjoyed the experience.

9AZn_AV71bAQ4LX1tkCNgQ.text: I had long wanted to try  this restaurant, but frankly was very disappointed. The service was adequate, but nothing more and we were treated rather as an afterthought.The food was good but pricey and the wine list OK, but again very pricey.I know this is central London but Benares and the Tamarind offer a much better ambience, better surroundings and better food at the same price.I'm glad I tried it, but won't bother again

AjNraGsvqj6pQi89Rz6I2g.text: REOPENED RECENTLY--- On the 10th of July 09 the biggest blaze in Central London after a decade in Dean Street (Soho), the historic building next door to The Red Fort which was used by film companies went up in flames. It took 100 fire fighters over 12 hours to get the blaze under control. The Red Fort was very lucky to escape the blaze, unfortunately The Red Fort took direct smoke and other flying debris damage and suffered tremendous water flood damage which was used to get the blaze under control

K52wDdJ8e2nimA01NBolnA.text: Rip off place. Wouldn't go there. They charge 6 pounds for  cup of rice , Dal, and naan each. Avoid like the plague

tLpWzAOtk4hMo6FROt8mLw.text: Sensational! Never has food tasted so delicious - takes "finger licking good" to a whole new level. Where to begin - upon entering the the restaurant, you're greeted by a friendly team of staff (always a bonus). The interior has a cool modern vibe, yet a comfy feel. The cocktails are to die for!! - A bomb of flavour that is so more ish, you'll definitely want to have more than one. For starters I went for monk fish   - best starter ever!! I opted for a lamb bryani (super generous portion - I wish I ordered it to share). By far the best food I've ever experienced. I must say, being a high profile place it is a "splash the cash" kind of restaurant - but worth every penny! I'd highly recommend eating here - I'll certainly be making a return visit.

photos.caption: Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom. The amazing Monk fish starter
Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom. Yummmm
Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom

tMb-ExclNAOnYcHlNW2xyA.text: Some of the best Indian food I've had in a long time. Food was perfectly spiced, ordered many different apps, main courses and veggie side dishes, all cooked well. Some standouts for the starters:- softshell crab appetizer- selection platter (for 2)- seekh kabobGreat main courses & sides:- Prawn lime-leaf- Hyderbadi bhuna gosht (lamb)- Awadhi hiran (venison)- Methi alooOf course a selection of rice, naan and papadams.

vOO6J2eoBS1wdhd2f7uKVQ.text: I visit Red Fort often and love their variations on traditional Indian dishes. Ambience is upscale and relaxed and the wine list is good. The naan sampler is always a highlight.

QQiKOfdFRAIycQZcp7TQWw.text: To use the vernacular "Amazeballs". This is not your typical Indian restaurant menu in either the content or the delivery. We had some kind of mushroom appetizer that we ordered three more plates of, but everything came up promptly, hot, well presented and delicious.There's some kind of nightclub downstairs that is kind of lame, but you're in the heart of SoHo, so you can't really go wrong there.Total thumbs up and will be on my regulars for London

31Vu3xcA5KcmvoNDWits1A.text: * * * Update, brother. I have eaten here. Twice now. Once with a couple, and once with about 11 other people. Both times the food was very good, though I recommend not getting the tasting menu if you are with a group, as you don't really get as much food as I think you would get if you were by yourself. Strength in numbers, perhaps. * * *I've never eaten here, I've only been downstairs for drinks and music. And by that I mean drinks. I happen to know, or somehow knew, a guy who worked there. Dan, is his name. If he still works there I am nearly certain he wouldn't remember me.Anyways, it has a cool vibe, decent music, and nice, tucked away seating areas if you get there early enough. Bathrooms are nice. I heard the food is decent, but I haven't tried it. As I already mentioned. Why aren't you paying attention to me??

hTSKgWE9OrxRjaJdBqXraw.text: Amazing Indian food. Service was superb and the variety of flavors made this spot an easy favorite.

_qASH2buSbnp42RQuO6_Ow.text: Very good Indian food. A reasonable amount of options and well executed. We got a variety of meat and veg options and shared them. Decently priced for London's west end. I'd come back.

zAaMprda7NsdpBCMNVW1pw.text: I waver between 3-4 stars for this place... but it has decent Indian food, and friendly service. The Red Fort has a bit of a trendy/hipster feel to it. I've only been once, and the restaurant was fairly empty when we arrived for our reservation, but quickly filled up. We had the soft shell crab as a starter, and I got the slices of duck breast as a main. We also got the rice & breads to compliment our meal. My friends got some curries (I forgot which) and they liked them but they were fairly standard. The soft shell crab was pretty delicious and the duck was good although a bit heavy in sauce. We took our time and never felt rushed. Some of the menu items are a little pricey, but not terribly so. Overall, a good place to have dinner. I think the downstairs is a lounge; it looked like it was starting to get pretty packed by the time we were leaving so that's probably something worth checking out for next time!

noEQuRQxZFF7uZJVdg1RmQ.text: Great tasting Indian food in soho.  The biryani is excellent and the chicken curries fantastic.

jVJUiu5V2WDtX_2ZAXsHXA.text: The food here is interesting... I found the Indian "fusion" far less preferable than traditional Indian cuisine or other Asian fusion restaurants I have tried. In general, the flavors were too bitter and I was disappointed to have surprise cheese in a spinach patty. Cheese at Indian restaurants should only be paneer and where I can see it!That said, the decor is lovely and the waitstaff is very attentive. I did like that the food felt more "healthy" than other Indian cuisine restaurants since there were less heavy sauces. Also, the papaya chutney that came with the papadum was a refreshing twist.

photos.caption: Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom

Q8Gf7bnkFVseVu5w4Wnj1g.text: Wow - I always like to gauge an Indian restaurant by it's Chicken Tiki Masala and these folks are at the top of the charts. The only complaint was their attempt at a wine list. They also only have one beer. But, at the end of the day I'm there for the food. Will re-visit next time in town.

wQVJYG-32Tu1U24PU2Mdbw.text: Chic, stylist and attendant service, well seasoned and sophisticated mains and a dance floor in the basement to boot. It may not have a Michelin star, but it's very very good. The tandoori prawns were seasoned so well, yet brought forth the sweetness of the sea. The Meethi Aalo was a surprise hit and I have to say it was the most expensive, but tasty potato dish I have ever had. A must visit especially if you can snag a big Yelp discount coupon for checking in.

pmKZjBD-_d-2V_jJvf-sAg.text: Excellent dishes. Everything was fresh and of the highest quality. The wine selection was nicely varied, and we enjoyed the best Chardonnay in London here. Be prepared to pay for every single item.

GVfIHQscdtpLIcp_l8VTsg.text: I have just returned from celebrating a friend's birthday at The Red Fort. As we were a larger group we went for a set menu, a selection of red and white wine, without wasting much time looking at the menu. Everything at The Red Fort is just that little bit nicer than your average Indian restaurant. All dishes were tastefully arranged and delicious. I felt sorry not to eat seafood or red meat, as even those looked rather inviting.I was particularly impressed with the plate of fresh fruit served for dessert  they were a good example of the high quality of ingredients, all pieces being just ripe despite being out of season.The shock arrived with the bill as none of us had expected to pay £100 for a curry. Gulp.

oPNTaTcp5bY_FfDK-_TuJA.text: There aren't many places that get 5 star reviews from me, particularly in London, but Red Fort is probably the best Indian meal I've ever had. And I eat Indian food A LOT! My father and I stopped in here one Saturday evening for an early dinner and were seated immediately. First thing you'll notice is that the decor is very serene and upscale. Upon being seated, we were greeted promptly by a very nice waiter who dropped off some tasty papadums & chutney and went over some of the menu options. They have a Chef's Tasting menu for 45 quid that looked fantastic, but we decided to create a tasting menu of our own. Every single dish we ate was fantastic and the two of us couldn't stop talking about how amazing the flavors were. We ordered: SALMON TIKKA - Scottish salmon marinated with mustard, ginger & garlic, seared in tandoor £9KOTHMIRI SCALLOP - Scallop tikka marinated with mint, coriander & curry leaf £12TEEKHAY ALOO - Baby potatoes tempered with chilli, mustard & poppy seed £7MURGH BEMISAAL - French corn-fed chicken tikka breast pieces in a mildly spiced clove, herbs & tomato sauce £18DUMPUKHT BIRYANI - Welsh lamb & Basmati rice with spices, steamed in a sealed pot £20Everything on the menu looked so good, and the great thing is that none of the dishes were really your traditional items found at run-of-the-mill Indian restaurants. They all had a unique twist to them. The flavors of the herbs and spices really were marvelous. The only downside was that for £20, the servings were a little small, but we didn't really care. Total bill was £110 for 2, which isn't half bad for the quality of meal we got here. I highly recommend this restaurant. The location in Soho is great. The decor is wonderful. Staff are friendly and accommodating. And the food is absolutely stellar. Highly recommended as a date place as well!

gEE2zYKFka32zGpxE6VLWw.text: Always look forward to at least one indian meal when visiting the UK.   The Red Fort did not disappoint.  Food and ambiance was way better than typical Indian restaurant.

EtEsjxmdxcVrCskbquRjbg.text: Everything we had was delicious, from the curries and naan to the salmon tikka (which was the real star for me).  The downside was the order of salmon tikka came with three pieces, we ate two and expected the third to be included in our doggie bag (with excess curry and naan), but it was not.  Perhaps it was an oversight, perhaps it's the stigma of doggie bags in the UK, but I hope someone in the kitchen got to eat it.

6bPAj8PEQTdTrBgm72oH3w.text: Highly recommended by friend in florida. Great atmosphere. Good service. Food was excellent but got same quality food at 1/3 price later in trip. Bring your wallet.  I understand food is expensive in london but this seemed steep.

q6ht8frKyLYouKyj8O20_w.text: I came here on the recommendation of the concierge at my hotel.+1 for bottled Kingfisher, but -1 for the Voss bottled water (strange to have fancy Swedish water at an indian place... doesn't Kingfisher make bottled water too. =p jk!)I started with the pear salad.. WOW.  this is a delicious combination with almost a full pear sliced thinly + spinach + balsamic. Totally not very indian, but amazing none the less.The saffron rice was mediocre but was a good base for the amazingness to follow.The dal was nice but on the thicker side than I like, but I fell in love with the Okra (bindhi). Yum Yum Yum!After a big meal, of course I went for dessert. The mango kulfi was delicious and helped satiate my stomach and cleanse my palette.The ambiance here is amazing, and the floating flowers and candles in the basins of water is a beautiful touch.#Vegetarian review

13t2zsXl5q0qrMPw__3SRw.text: I"ve had better at a take-away.  In fact, I've not had as bad at a take-away. Service was terrible, food was incredibly boring.  I was sad to waste my night in London on this restaurant.

4dVmxCAVOa_vFrh8sHh2-Q.text: Honest and tasty high quality Indian food.Totally recommend.Forget lousy and colorful places! Here everything is quiet.

q7wQjt2RWDLmkUbzeJ7RDA.text: Great Indian food if you are visiting London. Very centrally located in the Soho district.  Did not have dinner but lunch was great.  As of 10/18 this place is closed.

TVlM7g1u5qxoDjCmhVgq6w.text: I had a great meal at the Red Fort. Decent service which was fast but not friendly. Very nice decor, I liked the skylight and they have a club in the basement. The kebabs were great and the rice entrees were good. The kulfi was great too.

elYIOeUzfzLUuVJQB8z90Q.text: We came here on a friend's recommendation. This place did not disappoint. We ordered several a la carte entrees to share and everything was delicious. My picky kids who don't like a lot of spices even said the enjoyed the food. Service was great. I would recommend this restaurant if you are looking for food Indian food in London. We will be back next time!

photos.caption: Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom

jsCZGYBoDjUKqreY8NshaA.text: The Red Fort is one my favorite Indian restaurants in London,  really like the ambiance and the food is tantalizing to the taste buds.  The tandoori options are delish, the curries left my mouth watering for more. If your looking for great Indian food you will find it here

m1qPBE77bLkx5tZRPsvvzg.text: We enjoyed dinner at The Red Fort on the last night in SOHO. The lamb was delicious and our service was very good. We look forward to coming back for dinner

mOetF6vkeqSADSaBpmALKA.text: Great Indian cuisine in a classy environment. Not your -sticky floor- dark alley restaurant. The food was spot on although the Murgh Kofta (minced chicken dumplings) were quite bland, the Mehti Paneer (cottage cheese in tomato sauce) and the Samundari Ratan (seafood in tomatosauce) were excellent.Decent wine list though quite pricy.

photos.caption: Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom

UGIjd9I6LZo79y3k-ApRmg.text: Had dinner here during a business trip, both food and cocktails were quite good.  The lamb biryani was delicious though a little mild, I would highly recommend getting a side of the daal makhani - it had a deep rich flavor.  I was traveling alone that night, and was a bit disappointed that the prix fixe menu is only for tables size 2 and larger, as that's often the best way to try food when traveling alone.  c'est la vie.

q5d3vb7uOBBCNjAUMvVKFA.text: We come to this restaurant every time we visit London. It is the best Indian in London period. The is no fault to this establishment.The menu is a cornucopia of dishes cooked in tradition with sophistication., The wine list is spectacular with wine from every European city and beyond. The Chicken Tikka is stand alone hands down. If you prefer a spicier dish, request the chicken with cardamon from tandoor or for the spicy lentils.Try the tasting menu which is apx 40£ each. Three man starters, main courses and desert at the finish. Nam bread and Pappadorm included.

photos.caption: Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom

WFKg0k4dPw5xoBNh4iecsg.text: Phenomenal curries and romantic atmosphere. Had the most amazing lamb I've had in London. Absolutely recommended!

YpL_zITactXHE1_APeXhEA.text: This restaurant is amazing!!!  They have the best Indian food you will ever taste. The lamb curry is amazing!!  The best I've ever had. It's a bit spicy but is super tender. The bread, hummus, and dips are fantastic, as well and such a variety of flavors. There is something for everyone, wether you like sweet or spicy. We also tried the sea bass, which I loved!!!  It was so fresh. We will definitely return next time we are in London!!

_qnmKsom2bzM2qR6QFxTbA.text: Damn. This place has absolutely fantastic food, and it has a better ambiance than most Indian places I've been.  I had the black cod cooked in banana leaves, with coconut rice on the side. That was outstanding, and my girlfriend had the tikka masala, which is always a win.  The naan we ordered was comprised of three different types and all of them were perfect.  There's even a little bar/lounge downstairs that had some cool music playing, if having a quick drink after the meal is the plan. Highly, highly recommended. I wish this place was in my home town so I could go often.

71YsFtQfsmmMmwjXNy3O-Q.text: Without a doubt, the best Indian food I've ever had. I've been coming here for 15 years, and it's amazing. Simply the best.

_xW7Kb419lBTjOWIgSgn0A.text: A definite recommendation to dine at Fort Red for Indian cuisine.Located in the fringe of Soho, Fort Red is surprisingly beautifully laid out and decorated.  The food is outstanding and service (wait staff, sommelier) impeccable.  My colleagues and I ordered the special of the day consisting of four appetizers (prawns, scallop, chicken, vegetarian dish), four entrees (chicken, lamb, lentil, sea bass), and dessert (mango sherbet) - every dish teased our palate and teased our senses.  The sommelier recommended a white (Pinot) that complemented our meal.  London is renowned for its Indian cuisine, Fort Red lives up to the hype and a definite must visit again.

yUd8BFnCnfUnT5pHttDqHA.text: I think I really had the best Indian food in The Red Fort in Soho since the last time I was in India. The dishes are just like I remember the Indian food in the better restaurants in India.For example the Bhalla Sev Puri starter is a very Indian vegetarian starter. it is some kind of dumpling with yoghurt and puffs filled with potato, mint & tamarind chutney and it was really great, as was the seekh kebab (clearly non-veg).As mains we shared Chicken Tikka and a gravy/tomato sauce chicken dish Dum Kha Murgh with some butter naan and I loved it. Being a kind of fancy restaurant we had an excellent wine with the food.I guess this is not the most economic Indian restaurant in London but off course you can consider yourself warned while entering through the door covered in Michelin stickers.

HzuP7DA8ynzjmvo1RvUrew.text: Located near/ in London Chinatown. Quiet and smallish inside, the staff was friendly. The tikka masala was delish, tandoori juicy and Malai kofta spot on. Can't wait to go back again!

photos.caption: Photo of The Red Fort - London, United Kingdom

J2Qvyiw04aMRJnYcK2Rcjw.text: I had been coming to Red fort for a few times as it's less cumbersome to eat alone here vs many michelin star Indian restaurants in London. So I decided to run an experiment. Ok, I ate at Benares yesterday and it was awesome - no freaking complaints. They had amazing Jumbo Shrimps, Seekh Kebabs etc. Their Lamb main course was so good that I thought it was from another universe. I decided to eat dinner in Red Fort today so that I could compare. Ordered almost the same dishes and I was blown away. Their food was better, slightly! They work harder. That said, the ladies in Benares are more pleasing on the eyes ;)

3oAT7TvWEAnhsFoCtKu9Ew.text: Maybe 3 1/2 stars.  Good Indian food, creative menu but eclectic,  can be difficult to match the description in the menu with the dish that arrives on the table. Ask lots of questions. Service was very good and attentive. Portions are small, especially rice and naan which you will pay extra for. Prices are not ridiculous but a bit high for what is presented.

Sa_OHC6W2vIFZVleD3J4Uw.text: This so far has been our best meal of our European vacation. The north Indian fare at this restaurant was excellent. The flavors were so complex and layers upon layers; there were wonderful things to find in each dish. The names to the dishes were not familiar to me but we selected the pre-theather fixed menus composed of a chicken, lamb and vegetarian curry. Excellent is the only word that comes to mind. It's been 7 days since that meal and I still think about it. Should I ever find myself in London again, I will surely find my way back to this restaurant.

b2-wIXdPzUOhNDhSSne2qA.text: I admit that I went to Red Fort only because the line at Dishoom was ~2 hours; the first hour standing outside before you could even get to the bar for a drink! However it has always been on my list of upscale Indian restaurants I have wanted to try.The food was an interesting combination of dishes I know and love (and cook), like the Bhuna Gosht, and new items, like the scallop appetizer. My overall impression was that the food as very tasty and the level of service very good.I would definitely recommend it and would definitely go back.
